title: Saul rediscover scoring touch to eliminate Clann
story:
SAUL produced a sublime display to overwhelm Clann na Banna at a resplendent Pairc Eoghan Rua on Thursday night and consigned their first round defeat to Ballymartin to the book of harsh lessons learned.

Donnan Ritchie&rsquos Division 3 table-toppers were out of the traps in a flash and never gave the Banbridge outfit a sniff with an imperious display of expansive, attacking football.

Two early points from the impressive Cathail Arnold had Saul up and running and although Gary Quinn retaliated for Clann na Banna with a point in the fifth minute, it didn&rsquot take long for the Blue and Gold to forge ahead.

Two further Arnold points gave Saul a 0-4 to 0-1 lead after eight minutes before &lsquokeeper Gareth Brown saved his side&rsquos bacon when he produced a brilliant save to deny Paul Morgan an almost certain goal.

Kieran Maguire converted the resultant 45&rsquo before the roving Ciaran Harney and Liam Devlin swapped points to leave Saul with a two-point lead after 12 minutes.

Arnold, who was the perfect target man at full forward, broke free from Barry Nelson&rsquos clutches and combined with Pearse Laverty and Lorcan Harney before drilling the ball past a helpless Michael McAllister to put Saul into a 1-5 to 0-3 lead after 13 minutes.

Mark Loughlin&rsquos side then plundered the next two scores through frees from Maguire and Darren Brooker, but it was Saul who had the last say of the first half when Jamie&nbsp

Morgan pointed his side into a 1-6 to 0-6 lead at the break.

Clann na Banna were then subjected to a concerted blitzkrieg at the start of the second half with Saul attacking from all fronts and six unanswered points from Ciaran Harney , Caolan Magee and Niall Laverty and Pierce Laverty gave them a 1-12 to 0-6 lead with 42 minutes played.

Clann na Banna hit back with a Brooker free and a point from Conor Cole, but an effortless 45&rsquo from Arnold and a sizzling goal from the swashbuckling Callum Mahoney had Saul in dreamland.&nbsp

However, Clann na Banna were not for rolling over just yet and scores from Devlin, Maguire and Patrick Feeney cut Saul&rsquos lead to eight points with eight minutes remaining.

Saul sensed the danger and simply upped the intensity again with points from Pearse Laverty and will o&rsquo the wisp Ciaran Harney.

Rory Hill and Magee exchanged scores before Ciaran Harney responded as Saul took a 3-16 to 0-12 lead as the game drew to a conclusion. Jack Moan took the last&nbsp

score of the game for Clann na Banna, but they were a well beaten side on the final whistle.

Saul: G Brown, M Magill, A King, D Toner, J Mahoney, C Byrne, C Mahoney , J Morgan , P Laverty , L Harney, N Laverty , C Magee , C Harney , C Arnold , D Curran. Subs: D Napier for Magill , J Hampton for Toner, J Hayes for J Mahoney, B Cunningham for Magee, S Burns for P Laverty.&nbsp

Clann na Banna: M McAllister, A Nelson, B Nelson, S Nelson, S McGarry, D Lennon, S Lenaghan, D Brooker , J Treacy, K Maguire, G Quinn , P Morgan, P Feeney , L Devlin , R Hill . Subs: M Loughlin for McGarry, M McNally for Feeney, J Moan  for Hill.&nbsp

Saul 3-16

Clann na Banna 0-12

title: Shane Todd stand up show comes for Portaferry
story:
BEING named after an iconic Wild West film hero is a lot for anyone to live up to. Is Shane Todd a hero? Maybe. But also maybe not.&nbsp

Shane rides into Portaferry next month as part of his first tour of Ireland, with a hilarious, brand new stand-up &lsquoHero&rsquo show.

Shane performs stand-up all over the world, has a BBC radio series, supported the legendary Bill Burr and has gained a massive online following with his sketches and character videos.&nbsp

As Culture Northern Ireland states in their review: &lsquoNotions of Alan Partridge and Larry David crowd in. But the scale and the delivery are all Todd&rsquos own, and he delivers it perfectly.&rsquo

See him in his natural environment, on stage at a comedy show, at Portico on Saturday, September 15.

The performance starts at 7.30pm and tickets are &pound14. For details visit: http:www.porticoards.

title: Strangford Lough turbine removal
story:
THE world&rsquos first underwater turbine generator on Strangford Lough will soon be no more.

A major decommissioning operation on the revolutionary Seagen tidal generator is currently taking place.

All that remains of the &pound10m project installed ten years ago is a solitary tower which will be removed in November.

However, the removal of Seagen does not mean the end of tidal generated power on Strangford Lough.

Two smaller experimental underwater turbines have been installed on the seabed off Portaferry and it is understood that another turbine could be in operation by 2020.

The dismantling operation began last week and involved a massive crane being taken into the middle of the lough aboard a 44-metre barge which came from Troon in Scotland.

The first part of the operation involve the removal of the cross-beam which held the turbine blades.

On Sunday two massive lifting legs were removed and on Monday the control pod was taken off the top of the central tower.

Yesterday a lid was welded on to the top of the tower and the navigation lights were reinstated. The tower will be removed between November and April.

For many local people the dismantling work marks the end of an era. The world&rsquos press watched when Seagen was towed into place in March 2008 and hopes were high that it would be a source of clean and cheap electricity.

It was the world&rsquos first and largest tidal energy generator and was specifically designed for the fast-flowing waters of the Strangford Narrows.

A spokesman for owners Simec Atlantis Energy said: &ldquoEven during decommissioning SeaGen continues to provide invaluable information to help us understand the engineering and environmental requirements related to the complete life-cycle of a tidal stream development.

&ldquoSeaGen has played a pivotal role in the development of tidal energy technology, installed in 2008 SeaGen delivered 10 GWh of electricity to the Northern Ireland grid.&nbsp

&ldquoThe engineering lessons learnt and operational experience gathered during installation and operation advanced the development of SeaGen tidal technology. The environmental data has furthered the understanding of the environmental impacts of tidal technology upon the marine environment.

The spokesman added: &ldquoThe SeaGen Project has been a resounding success. Atlantis continues to utilise the data acquired in Strangford to explore development opportunities at tidal sites around the world.
